div.head: AN EXTRACT OF THE REGISTERS OF PARLEMENT.
div.p:
THis pre≈øent day the King's Attorney-General came into the Court of Parliament, and alledged, that the Report being publickly ≈øpread up and down, That the Pope had enjoyned the General of the Je≈øuits, to direct to the Provincials of Paris and Tholou≈øe authentical Copies of the Brief i≈ø≈øued out by his Holine≈øs, on the fir≈øt day of this pre≈øent year, together with a more particular Injunction to him of Tholou≈øe, to publi≈øh it, and to oblige tho≈øe of that Society, to affirm the Reality of the ≈øaid Brief, contrary to the Opinion, which we were de≈øirous that men ≈øhould ≈øtill have had of it; As al≈øo that the General of the Je≈øuits having written to tho≈øe Provincials, pur≈øuantly to that Precept of the Pope, had ≈øent to him of Tholou≈øe an Authentical Expedition of that Brief, with an Order that it might be communicated to that of Paris: This new Method and Invention of publi≈øhing Bulls and Briefs in the Kingdom, contrary to the Forms which had been ob≈øerved to this pre≈øent time; as well in this as the neighbouring Countreys, ≈øeem'd to be of ≈øo great con≈øequence, that he accounted it his duty to inform the Court of it, to the end, that if that Report prov'd to be true, they might be pleas'd to ob≈øtruct the e≈øtabli≈øhment of an Innovation, the Con≈øequences whereof might be ≈øo dangerous, and particularly at ≈øuch a time, when ≈øuch
extraordinary Briefs are ≈øeen to come abroad. But repre≈øenting withal, that the Prudence and Ju≈øtice of the Court of Parlement, not permitting him to act upon uncertain grounds, it was his humble Reque≈øt to them, that they would be plea≈øed, con≈øidering the ab≈øence of the Provincial, to ≈øummon in the Superiour of the Profe≈øs'd Hou≈øe, the Rectors of the Colledge, and of the Noviciat of the Je≈øuits, and the Procurator of the Province of Paris, to give an account to the ≈øaid Court of Parlement, in the pre≈øence of him the Attorney-General, and his Collegues, of what they know concerning that Report, that the Court may proceed therein, upon the Conclu≈øions which they ≈øhould take, after they have been more particularly inform'd by that means.

The ≈øaid Attorney-General having with-drawn, and the Matter being taken into Deliberation, it was re≈øolv'd, that the Superiour of the Profe≈øs'd Hou≈øe of the Je≈øuits, the Rectors of the Colledge, and the Noviciat, and the Procurator of the Province of Paris ≈øhould be ≈øummon'd to appear in Court, on Friday at ≈øeven in the Morning, that they might be heard in the pre≈øence of the King's Council, and give an Account of what they knew of the ≈øaid Brief of January 1. 1681. and of the Orders which the Provincial receiv'd from the General upon that occa≈øion. And that done, that ≈øuch Order be taken therein, upon the Conclu≈øions of his Maje≈øties Council, as ≈øhall be requi≈øite.

div.head: An Extract of the Regi≈øters of Parliament.
div.p:
THis day the King's Council came into Court, and gave notice, that Father de Verthamont, Superiour of the Profe≈øs'd Hou≈øe of the Je≈øuits, of this City of Paris, the Fathers De≈øchamps, and Dozaine, Rectors of the Colledge, and of the
Noviciat, and Father Pallu, Procurator of the Province of France, were attending in the Lobby, in order to their receiving the plea≈øure of the Court, according to the Re≈øolve of the 18th. of that Month: Whereupon the ≈øaid Father-Je≈øuit, being brought into the pre≈øence of the King's Council, Men≈øieur the fir≈øt Pre≈øident thus ≈øpoke to them:

This Court hath ≈øummon'd you to appear here, upon the Adverti≈øement given to us, that your General hath not long ≈øince ≈øent into France, by the Pope's Order, to ≈øome of your Provincials, a pretended Brief, in order to the publi≈øhing of it. This kind of procedure, quite oppo≈øite to the Orders of the Kingdom, has always been di≈øallow'd with Reproach again≈øt its Authors, as often as they have attempted to put it in practice. It is a ≈øtrange thing that a Prince, who has not ceas'd conquering, till ≈øuch time as he was pleas'd to do ≈øo, and who has given Peace to Europe cannot enjoy it him≈øelf, and that he is not di≈øturbed therein, but by the principal Mini≈øters of Truth, while he expends his Cares and Trea≈øures for the De≈øtruction of Here≈øie: But it is a Happine≈øs, that this Pacquet is fallen into Hands ≈øo re≈øerv'd as yours: We do not ≈øurprize your Wi≈ødom, nor do we corrupt your Fidelity. The Court de≈øires of you, that you would make it a Relation of what has pa≈øs'd upon this occa≈øion.

Father Verthamont acknowledg'd, that their Provincial had receiv'd a Letter from their General of the 23d. of April la≈øt, with a Copy in the Italian Language, of an Order of the Pope's, for the directing, to the Provincial of Tholou≈øe, a Copy, in an Authentical Form, of his Holine≈ø≈øe's Brief of the fir≈øt of January this pre≈øent year, concerning the Grand-Vicars, e≈øtabli≈øh'd in the Dioce≈øe of Pamiers, during the Vacancy of the See, and for enjoyning the Je≈øuits of Tholou≈øe and Pamiers to declare, that the ≈øaid Brief was real, and to addre≈øs a Copy of it, to the Provincial of Paris, that he might al≈øo be a≈ø≈øur'd of the Reality thereof. And by that Order, the General is charg'd to give an Account, to the
A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of the Inqui≈øition, of the An≈øwers which ≈øhould be made unto him. That in the ≈øame Pacquet, there was an un≈øigned Copy of that Brief. That he him≈øelf knew, that, by by way of An≈øwer to the General's Letter, their Provincial had, among other things, written to him, that he did not believe any one of his Society would would have been ≈øo unfortunate, as to make any diminution of the re≈øpect they owe his Holine≈øs, as he might al≈øo a≈ø≈øure the Court, on the behalf of all the Je≈øuits of the Kingdom, that they ≈øhould not ever be defective in point of Fidelity and Zeal for his Maje≈øty.

Whereupon Mon≈øieur Denys Talon, the King's Advocate, and one of his Council ≈øpoke thus: Sirs, It is apparent by what has been ju≈øt now ≈øaid, by the Superior of the Je≈øuits Hou≈øe of St. Lewis, in this City, That the General of the Je≈øuits had receiv'd an Order from the Pope, for his ≈øending to the Provincials of the Je≈øuits of Paris and Tholou≈øe, an authentical Copy of a Brief, dated the fir≈øt day of this pre≈øent year, which is pre≈øuppos'd to be directed to the Chapter of Pamiers, and to Friar Cerle, in the quality of the Grand Vicar of Pamiers, during the Vacancy of the See, and that with a De≈øign, that the Je≈øuits of Tholou≈øe and Pamiers, who, as it is pretended by ≈øome, had publickly affirm'd, that the ≈øaid Brief was not real, ≈øhould be oblig'd to retract it, to confe≈øs the reality of the Brief, and to acknowledge withal the fault they have committed by an affected Incredulity, and they would have it, that the General ≈øhould give an Account to the A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of the Inqui≈øition of the An≈øwers which ≈øhall be made unto him. This Order, which does not appear to have any Date, is accompany'd with a Copy of the Brief, but not Signed, and by a Letter of the General's, repeating the ≈øame thing contained in the Pope's Order. It is ea≈øily di≈øcoverable by this ≈øimple Expo≈øition of the matter of Fact, that this manner of de≈øigning to publi≈øh, and in ≈øome ≈øort to execute Briefs in the Kingdom, is new, contrary to the Laws of the Country, and of a dangerous Con≈øequence. It is not only in France,
that Briefs and other important Expeditions of the Court of Rome cannot be either publi≈øh'd or put in Execution, without the King's permi≈ø≈øion. The ≈øame thing is practic'd in Spain, and in mo≈øt of the other Countreys, wherein the Authority of the Holy See is acknowledg'd.

The Corre≈øpondence which ought to be between the two Powers, the Intere≈øt which Sovereign Princes have to prevent the Introduction of any thing from abroad, tending to the di≈øturbance of the Tranquility of their Governments, has render'd this Cu≈øtom legal and nece≈ø≈øary: But that wi≈øe precaution, which many times di≈øpen≈øes with our entring into more intricate Conte≈øtations, would be of no Advantage, if the Contrivance which they have made u≈øe of at Rome, in order to the publi≈øhing of the Brief of the fir≈øt of January be authorized; in regard that, as often as there ≈øhall be any Bulls, which they would have received in the Kingdom, and yet ≈øuch as whereof his Maje≈øty will not think convenient to permit either the Execution or Publication, they will make u≈øe of the interpo≈øition of the Generalls of Orders, who, for the mo≈øt part have their Re≈øidence at Rome. And the Pope by, their Channell, will pretend to get into France all the Decrees of the Inqui≈øition, and in a word, all the Encroachments which the Court of Rome would make upon our Liberties.

It is therefore nece≈ø≈øary to check the cour≈øe of ≈øo dangerous an Innovation; which yet may be done with ≈øo much the more ea≈øe, that, as to that concern, there is not any nece≈ø≈øity of e≈øtabli≈øhing new Laws. It is only requi≈øite that we keep our ≈øelves from di≈øpen≈øing with the ob≈øervation of the ancient Ordinances, which do not allow of the publication of any Brief or Bull, from Rome, without the King's permi≈ø≈øion. And this is done in ≈øome Provinces with ≈øo much Rigour, that the very ≈øimple Signatures of Provi≈øions of Benefices are not exempted from that General Order, whether they come from Rome, or the Legation of Avignon. What we do in this Juncture for the Publick Intere≈øt, and his Maje≈øties
Service, proceeds not from our having Cau≈øe to complain of the Je≈øuits; the Reproaches which they receive in the Direction, written in the Pope's Name, and in their General's Letter, ought, among≈øt us, to ≈øtand them in≈øtead of an Elogy, and are certain Proofs, that they have not deviated from their Duty. And therefore ≈øince it may be ≈øome di≈ø≈øatisfaction to them, that they cannot ≈øubmit to the Orders of the Pope and their General, in ca≈øe they are not inform'd, how oppo≈øite that Order is to the Laws of the Kingdom, it is but ju≈øt that we relieve them, and rid them out of the perplexity, which they might run into by the Authority of the Decree which will be pa≈øs'd. But if we have not hitherto u≈øed endeavours to prevent the Publication of the Brief of the fir≈øt of January; if we have look'd upon the Copies, which have been ≈øcatter'd up and down of it in Paris, rather as Libels, than Copies of an authentical Act, it has not been out of any Fear, but is to be attributed to our moderation, as being inclineable to doubt of their reality. We ≈øhall not want Remedies to oppo≈øe Enterprizes of that Nature, when it ≈øhall not be allowable in us to connive at them any longer. We ≈øhall u≈øe our utmo≈øt endeavours to continue the good Corre≈øpondence which ought to be between His Maje≈øty and the Pope, between the Holy See, and the Gallicane Church; and whatever may happen, we ≈øhall never, on our part, make a Breach of that Sacred Union of the Sacerdotal Function, and the Royalty, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary to keep up the Splendor of both the Powers, and to pre≈øerve and dilate Religion.

But on the other ≈øide, we ≈øhall not endure the Impo≈øition of a Yoke, which our Fathers have not undergone, nor the Abolition of our Liberties, of which they were ≈øo jealous. We ≈øhall never approve of any Alteration in the Order of Juri≈ødictions. When the Pope receives Appeals from Eccle≈øia≈øtical Judgments, he is oblig'd to nominate Judges in the Kingdom, for the termination of them, and he cannot entertain
affairs there at fir≈øt breaking out, nor retain the cognizance thereof at Rome, whether it be in reference to the validity of Elections, or even of Appeals from Sentences given by Bi≈øhops, or other Officials. As we are inclin'd to a Religious ob≈øervation of the Concordate, and do tolerate Re≈øignations in favour, Preventions, Annates (that is annual Tenths) though contrary to the ancient di≈øcipline of the Church; So ought the Pope to execute it on his ≈øide al≈øo, in the things that are favourable to us, which we do not look upon as Priviledges granted us by Rome, but as the exerci≈øe of common right, and as the Ground-work of our Immunities. And it is thereby ea≈øily perceivable, that tho≈øe per≈øons, who are the Authors of the Brief of the fir≈øt of January, and of many others, which have appear'd upon this matter, engage the Pope in conte≈øts more likely to retrench his Authority, than to augment it, and ≈øeem to have no other de≈øign, than that of di≈øturbing the Peace of the Church. In ≈øhort, the Regale being one of the mo≈øt eminent rights of the Crown, how can they hope that the King will ever endure that that Illu≈øtrious Prerogative ≈øhould, during his Reign, admit of the lea≈øt ≈øhock or diminution? Your own Records acquaint you, that the Regale was always ≈øo con≈øider'd as a right of the Crown, unalienable and impre≈øcriptible, that King Francis the Fir≈øt, having left Madam Loui≈øe of Savoy, his Mother, Regent in the Kingdom, and having, among≈øt other things, inve≈øted her with a power to confer Benefices, vacant in the Regal donation, ≈øhe was oblig'd to renounce that Priviledge, upon the Remon≈øtrances of the Parlement, who repre≈øented to her, that the right of conferring Benefices, in the Regal Donation, was ≈øo annex'd to the King's Per≈øon, that he could never part with it, or communicate it to any other. The Judgment of particular, or general Controver≈øies, ari≈øing in the matters of the Regale, do belong, and ever have belong'd to this Honourable A≈ø≈øembly, privatively to all other Tribunals of the Kingdom. It was your Honourable Body judg'd it above ≈øeventy
years ≈øince, that the Regale extended over all Bi≈øhopricks, without any di≈øtinction; and the Declarations of MDCLXXIII, and MDCLXXV, do not make any new E≈øtabli≈øhment, and do but confirm your Decree. So that we may confidently affirm, that how great ≈øoever the King's Authority may be, yet he can no more renounce the Regale, either wholly, or in part, than he can de≈øtroy the Salick Law, or abandon the Sovereignty of ≈øome part of the Provinces, which make up and integrate the French Monarchy; and what ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion ≈øoever we may have for his Will and Plea≈øure, we ≈øhall rather be≈øeech him to di≈øburthen us of the Exerci≈øe of our Charges, than endure, that that Priviledge ≈øhould receive the lea≈øt Diminution by our Suffrages, or our Silence. There is not any nece≈ø≈øity that a man ≈øhould be much vers'd in our Maxims, to di≈øcover, that it is not at Rome the≈øe Que≈øtions ought to be di≈øcu≈øs'd, and that whatever has been hitherto done, either on the account of the Pope, or his Officers, is equally unmaintainable, as well in the form, as the groundwork of it. 'Tis to no purpo≈øe that they menace with Excommunication, not only the Eccle≈øia≈øticks, but the very Prelates of the Kingdom, when they do not implicitely ≈øubmit to Briefs contrary to our manners, and ≈øuch as would ab≈øolutely aboli≈øh the Epi≈øcopal Juri≈ødiction, if the Execution thereof were permitted. Appeals, in the ca≈øe of abu≈øes, introduc'd to maintain the Policy of the Church, and to ob≈øtruct the u≈øurpations of the Officers of the Court of Rome upon the Temporal and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction, are infallible expedients to ≈øecure all the King's Subjects from tho≈øe Cen≈øures, which our Ance≈øtors have ≈ølighted, and declared abu≈øive, when there was no legal Ground for them.

Having thus prote≈øted, as we do, that we ≈øhall u≈øe all the means, which we ≈øhall think convenient, to check the cour≈øe of all the≈øe Innovations, and to put a period to attempts ≈øo prejudicial to the King's Authority, and the Immunities of the Gallicane Church; It is our reque≈øt, that the Court will
be pleas'd to order the Copy of the Brief of the fir≈øt of January, the Italian Memoirs ≈øent to the General of the Je≈øuits, and the Letter by him written to the Provincial of the Province of Fance, to be regi≈øtred among≈øt the Records of the Court, to the end, that after Communication had of them what is fitting may be required; That there be a prohibition i≈ø≈øued out to the Provincial, and to all the Superiours of the Hou≈øes of the Je≈øuits, again≈øt the publi≈øhing of the ≈øaid Brief, Letters, and Memoires, and doing any thing as to the Execution thereof, directly or indirectly, under any pretence what≈øoever, upon pain of an extraordinary procedure again≈øt tho≈øe who ≈øhall not obey, as di≈øturbers of the publick tranquillity; as al≈øo upon pain, as to the Society, of the Forfeiture of all the rights, priviledges, and prerogatives, which are attributed thereto, as well by its e≈øtabli≈øhment, as otherwi≈øe. That the like Prohibitions be made to all the Superiours, nay to all the individual per≈øons of the Religious Communities, again≈øt publi≈øhing, or executing any Bull or Brief, otherwi≈øe than pur≈øuantly to Letters-Patents well and duly verify'd in Court, and that under the ≈øame penalties: And that to that end, the Decree which is to pa≈øs upon the pre≈øent conclu≈øions ≈øhall be read in all places, where it ≈øhall be thought requi≈øite.

Mon≈øieur the Fir≈øt Pre≈øident pronounc'd his Opinion. The Court order'd, That the Copies of the pretended Brief, the Memoire containing the Pope's Order, and the Letter ≈øent, ≈øhall be immediately regi≈øtred, that they may be communicated to his Maje≈øties Attorney-General, and to the end, that, upon his Conclu≈øions in writing, ≈øuch provi≈øion ≈øhould be made therein as is requi≈øite. And after the Decree prononced, Mon≈øieur the Fir≈øt Pre≈øident ≈øaid to the Je≈øuits; The pre≈øent A≈ø≈øembly orders me to tell you, that they are ≈øatisfy'd with your obedience. The ≈øaid Pieces were regi≈øtred, and afterwards the King's Council withdrew.

And afterwards, upon the peru≈øal of the ≈øaid Pieces, and the Conclu≈øions taken in writing by the King's Attorney-General,
whereby he had required, That prohibitions ≈øhould be made to the ≈øaid Provincial and others of the ≈øaid Society, as to the publi≈øhing the ≈øaid Brief, and the orders receiv'd from the Pope, by the General of their Society, and doing any thing directly or indirectly executively thereto; And that Prohibitions ≈øhould be in like manner made to all Provincials, Superiours, and private per≈øons of all the Religious Orders, again≈øt their publi≈øhing and executing any Briefs, or Bulls of the Pope, other than the Briefs and Bulls, relating to the interiour and ordinary di≈øcipline of their Orders, otherwi≈øe than con≈øequentially to the King's Letters Patents, regi≈øter'd in the Court of Parlement, upon pain of an extraordinary procedure again≈øt all ≈øuch as ≈øhould be refractory, and, as to the ≈øaid Society and Religious Orders, upon the forfeiture of all the favours and priviledges which had been granted to them. The matter was taken into Deliberation.

THE COURT proceeding juridically upon the Conclu≈øi≈øions of the King's Attorney-General, does make prohibitions to the ≈øaid Provincial, and others of the Society of the Je≈øuits, as to the publi≈øhing the ≈øaid Brief, and Orders receiv'd from the Pope, by the General of their Society, and doing any thing directly or indirectly in the execution thereof. And it makes al≈øo mo≈øt expre≈øs prohibitions to all Provincials, Superiours, and Religious Per≈øons, of all Orders, that they do not publi≈øh or execute any Briefs or Bulls of the Pope, other than the Briefs and Bulls relating to the interiour and ordinary di≈øcipline of their Orders, otherwi≈øe than con≈øequentially to the King's Letters Patents regi≈øtred in the Court of Parlement, upon pain of extraordinary procedure again≈øt the refractory, and, in reference to the ≈øaid Society and Orders, of forfeiture of all the favours and priviledges which have been granted them by the King, and the Kings his Predece≈ø≈øors.
